title: Supermarket tycoon and ex-Miss Great Britain wife refused permission for dream home
text:
A millionaire supermarket chain owner and his Masterchef wife have had plans to build their dream coastal home blocked because of its 'boxy' style.

Chris Kiley, 60, and his former Miss Great Britain beauty queen wife Alice, 31, drew up the modern Grand Designs house complete with a super-kitchen overlooking a Welsh beauty spot.

Mr Kiley also wanted a huge open plan living area downstairs for himself and his wife Alice, who appeared on the TV cooking contest in 2013.

But their plans for the modern home with three bedrooms, two en-suites and walk-in wardrobes were kicked out by planners who said it would 'ruin the area'.

Chris Kiley (left) and his wife Alice (right) wanted to build on their existing property in Wales

The plans (pictured above) were opposed and the council received 14 letters of objection

The area where Mr Kiley wanted to build (pictured above) was hailed as Britain's first area of outstanding natural beauty (above a view of Caswell Bay)

The home was planned in the grounds of their £2.5million existing property overlooking Caswell Bay on the Gower, South Wales - Britain's first area of outstanding natural beauty.

Mr Kiley, who owns 20-strong supermarket chain CK Foodstore, said the home would fit 'seamlessly' into the character of the seafront.

He also said it was inspired by a nearby property and would enhance the Gower Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty.

The plans above show where the 'box' like property would sit on the edge and shows side elevation views

Novice surfers at a calm Caswell Bay, one of the most popular, easily accessible and closest beaches to Swansea City, on the Gower peninsula, South Wales

There were 14 letters of objection to the 'box-like' and 'incongruous' house - and Swansea Council planning officers turned the application down.

They said there was no 'satisfactory rural justification or need' for the new house and it had a 'poor general appearance.'

Mr Kiley then appealed the decision - which was again denied by a top planning inspector.

Welsh Government-appointed planning inspector Hywel Ceri Davies said the landscaped gardens on the site were a feature of the seafront's distinctive appearance.

Caswell Bay is a very Popular beach during the summer months with families and tourists

He said: 'In these circumstances there is no certainty that the proposal would result in a safe and satisfactory development of the site.'

It's not the first time Mr Kiley has upset communities in residential areas, in 2015 he was slammed for flying a helicopter through Heathrow airspace, after he was late to a lunch date.

Air traffic control were forced to halt international flights after he landed in a village car park.
